pages.raw_output:
<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 194, 220, 208]]<|/det|>
# MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 215, 356, 232]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Pure Mathematics 2 (P2)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 259, 460, 303]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Answer Booklet/Paper Graph Paper List of Formulae (MF9)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 320, 390, 337]]<|/det|>
READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 351, 828, 367]]<|/det|>
If you have been given an Answer Booklet, follow the instructions on the front cover of the Booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 368, 722, 384]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 384, 325, 400]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 400, 497, 416]]<|/det|>
You may use a soft pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 416, 601, 433]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 447, 284, 463]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 463, 907, 495]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 494, 590, 510]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 510, 606, 526]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 540, 606, 556]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 556, 756, 572]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 572, 440, 588]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 50.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 588, 907, 619]]<|/det|>
Questions carrying smaller numbers of marks are printed earlier in the paper, and questions carrying larger numbers of marks later in the paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 425, 94]]<|/det|>
Solve the inequality \(|x + 2| > \left|\frac{1}{2} x - 2\right|\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 123, 94, 141]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 120, 920, 144]]<|/det|>
Use logarithms to solve the equation \(4^{x + 1} = 5^{2x - 3}\), giving your answer correct to 3 significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 138, 920, 156]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 185, 94, 203]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[262, 193, 771, 375]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 395, 675, 415]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the curve \(y = x - 2\ln x\) and its minimum point \(M\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 427, 153, 445]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 427, 381, 445]]<|/det|>
Find the \(x\)-coordinate of \(M\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 427, 920, 445]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 458, 153, 476]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 457, 692, 477]]<|/det|>
Use the trapezium rule with three intervals to estimate the value of

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 483, 569, 521]]<|/det|>
\[\int_{2}^{5}(x - 2\ln x)\mathrm{d}x,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 526, 537, 546]]<|/det|>
giving your answer correct to 2 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 526, 920, 545]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 558, 151, 576]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 556, 920, 592]]<|/det|>
State, with a reason, whether the trapezium rule gives an under-estimate or an over-estimate of the true value of the integral in part (ii).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 574, 920, 592]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 619, 94, 637]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 618, 567, 638]]<|/det|>
Find the exact value of the positive constant \(k\) for which

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 642, 584, 680]]<|/det|>
\[\int_{0}^{k}\mathrm{e}^{4x}\mathrm{d}x = \int_{0}^{2k}\mathrm{e}^{x}\mathrm{d}x.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 655, 920, 673]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 718, 94, 737]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 718, 153, 737]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 718, 650, 738]]<|/det|>
By sketching a suitable pair of graphs, show that the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[455, 744, 541, 774]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{1}{x} = \sin x,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 784, 594, 803]]<|/det|>
where \(x\) is in radians, has only one root for \(0 < x \leqslant \frac{1}{2}\pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 784, 920, 803]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 816, 153, 833]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 814, 697, 833]]<|/det|>
Verify by calculation that this root lies between \(x = 1.1\) and \(x = 1.2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 814, 920, 833]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 848, 149, 867]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 846, 920, 890]]<|/det|>
Use the iterative formula \(x_{n + 1} = \frac{1}{\sin x_n}\) to determine this root correct to 2 decimal places. Give the result of each iteration to 4 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 878, 920, 895]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 73, 437, 92]]<|/det|>
The parametric equations of a curve are

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[379, 100, 616, 120]]<|/det|>
\[x = 1 + 2\sin^{2}\theta ,\quad y = 4\tan \theta .\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 140, 156, 159]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 138, 390, 168]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\frac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x} = \frac{1}{\sin\theta\cos^3\theta}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 144, 920, 163]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 183, 153, 201]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 181, 920, 217]]<|/det|>
Find the equation of the tangent to the curve at the point where \(\theta = \frac{1}{4}\pi\), giving your answer in the form \(y = mx + c\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 201, 920, 218]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 246, 96, 265]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 243, 920, 280]]<|/det|>
The polynomial \(ax^{3} - 3x^{2} - 11x + b\), where \(a\) and \(b\) are constants, is denoted by \(\mathrm{p}(x)\). It is given that \((x + 2)\) is a factor of \(\mathrm{p}(x)\), and that when \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) is divided by \((x + 1)\) the remainder is 12.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 291, 153, 310]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 291, 373, 310]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(a\) and \(b\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 291, 920, 310]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 323, 153, 342]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 323, 630, 342]]<|/det|>
When \(a\) and \(b\) have these values, factorise \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) completely.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 323, 920, 342]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 368, 94, 387]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 368, 148, 387]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 368, 920, 403]]<|/det|>
Express \(5\cos \theta - 3\sin \theta\) in the form \(R\cos (\theta + \alpha)\), where \(R > 0\) and \(0^\circ < \alpha < 90^\circ\), giving the exact value of \(R\) and the value of \(\alpha\) correct to 2 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 387, 920, 405]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 415, 151, 435]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 415, 361, 435]]<|/det|>
Hence solve the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 435, 581, 454]]<|/det|>
\[5\cos \theta - 3\sin \theta = 4,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 459, 546, 479]]<|/det|>
giving all solutions in the interval \(0^{\circ}\leqslant \theta \leqslant 360^{\circ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 459, 920, 478]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 490, 151, 509]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 490, 626, 509]]<|/det|>
Write down the least value of \(15\cos \theta - 9\sin \theta\) as \(\theta\) varies.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 490, 920, 509]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]
